statement.text: Popliteal artery injury, most commonly associated with knee dislocation or fractures involving the distal femur or proximal tibia, carries the highest amputation rate of any extremity arterial injury (10-15%) due to limited collateral circulation and the time-critical nature of revascularization.

explanation.intuition: The popliteal artery is tethered behind the knee, passing through a tight space where it can't move out of the way. When the knee dislocates or a severe fracture occurs, the artery gets stretched or torn. Because there are few good backup blood vessels around the knee, the leg below can die quickly without repair.
explanation.key_insight: Knee dislocation = popliteal artery injury until proven otherwise. Even when the knee has spontaneously reduced, 20-40% have arterial injury. The '6-hour rule' for limb salvage is well-established - delays beyond 6-8 hours of warm ischemia dramatically increase amputation rates. Immediate vascular surgery consultation is mandatory.
explanation.technical_details: The popliteal artery is the continuation of the superficial femoral artery at the adductor hiatus, running through the popliteal fossa and trifurcating into anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and peroneal arteries. It is relatively fixed at the adductor hiatus above and the soleus arch below, making it vulnerable to stretch injury. Knee dislocation (especially anterior and posterior) has 20-40% arterial injury rate. Collateral circulation via geniculate arteries is usually inadequate for acute occlusion. The golden rule: warm ischemia time <6 hours for optimal limb salvage. Management algorithm: ABC, assess pulses/ABI, CTA if ABI abnormal or high suspicion, immediate exploration for hard signs. Repair with reversed saphenous vein graft preferred. Four-compartment fasciotomy mandatory if ischemia >4-6 hours or significant swelling.

knee_dislocation.mechanism: Stretch injury at fixed points above and below

fractures.proximal_tibia: Tibial plateau fractures with dislocation component

etiology.penetrating: GSW, stab wounds to popliteal fossa

examination: Pulse examination (may be normal with intimal injury)
assessment.ABI_threshold: ABI <0.9 mandates further evaluation; some use <0.8
assessment.imaging: CTA is first-line for stable patients with abnormal ABI
assessment.observation_pitfall: Intimal flap may cause delayed thrombosis - serial exams essential

ischemia_tolerance.golden_period: 6 hours warm ischemia for optimal limb salvage
ischemia_tolerance.myoglobin_release: Reperfusion after prolonged ischemia causes rhabdomyolysis

immediate.reduction: Reduce dislocation to relieve arterial kinking

operative.repair: Reversed saphenous vein interposition graft preferred over prosthetic
operative.spanning_fixator: May apply before or after vascular repair depending on stability
operative.sequence: Vascular repair first if actively ischemic; temporary shunt if fixation needed first

fasciotomy.indication: Ischemia >4-6 hours, significant swelling, post-revascularization edema
fasciotomy.technique: Four-compartment fasciotomy (anterior, lateral, deep posterior, superficial posterior)
fasciotomy.timing: Better prophylactic than therapeutic - low threshold

outcomes.functional_outcome: Often limited even with limb salvage due to associated nerve and soft tissue injury

definition.@value: Traumatic injury to the popliteal artery, commonly from knee dislocation, carrying the highest amputation rate of extremity arterial injuries due to limited collateral circulation and time-critical nature of repair.

learning_objectives: Recognize the association between knee dislocation and popliteal artery injury
Apply the 6-hour rule for limb-threatening ischemia
Perform systematic assessment of popliteal injuries
Understand the rationale for prophylactic fasciotomy
clinical_pearls: Knee dislocation = popliteal injury until proven otherwise (20-40% incidence)
Popliteal injury has HIGHEST amputation rate of any extremity artery (10-15%)
6-hour rule: warm ischemia >6 hours dramatically increases amputation risk
ABI <0.9 mandates further evaluation - CTA or exploration
Normal pulse does NOT rule out intimal injury - may thrombose later
Four-compartment fasciotomy mandatory if ischemia >4-6 hours
Vein graft preferred over prosthetic for contaminated/traumatic field
